title: Erdős Problem #662: Distances in Separated Point Sets
description: For 1-separated points in ℝ², is the number of pairs at distance ≤ t maximized by the triangular lattice? f(1)=6, f(√3)=12, f(3)=18. Erdős–Lovász–Vesztergombi. Open.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős, Lovász, and Vesztergombi posed this problem in 1997 about the optimality of the triangular lattice for maximizing short-range distances in separated point sets. It connects to the classical hexagonal packing theorem and contact number problems.
overview.problemStatement: For n points in ℝ² with pairwise distance ≥ 1, is the number of pairs at distance ≤ t maximized by the triangular lattice configuration?
overview.proofStrategy: We define 1-separated point sets, the pair count function, and the triangular lattice count f(t). We state the optimality conjecture and record known lattice values.
keyInsights: The triangular lattice has f(1)=6, f(√3)=12, f(3)=18 neighbors within distance t
The conjecture extends hexagonal packing optimality to distance pair counting
The case t=1 relates to the contact number problem: max unit distances = 3n − O(√n)
The original problem statement contains a known typo
Connects to Thue's circle packing theorem in ℝ²

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #662 asks whether the triangular lattice maximizes the number of pairs at distance ≤ t among 1-separated point sets in ℝ². This extends the classical hexagonal packing optimality to a distance counting problem.
conclusion.implications: Confirming the conjecture would establish the triangular lattice as the universal extremal configuration for short-range pair interactions, with applications to crystallography and optimal packing theory.
openQuestions: Is the triangular lattice the unique maximizer for all t ≥ 1?
What happens for non-integer multiples of lattice distances?
Does the analogous result hold in higher dimensions (FCC lattice)?
Can the contact number case (t=1) be resolved independently?
